doc.previous: The afternoon Chicago papers trumpeted that "strike leader" Albert Parsons had been "arrested" that day â neither of which things were true.[17] The Chicago strike of 1877 was ultimately violently repressed by the action of the police and militia and order in the city was restored.
doc.after: At the turn of the decade, Albert Parsons withdrew from all participation in electoral politics. He later recalled his rationale in his memoirs, written shortly before his execution in 1887:
